t: There*p is an evil which I have seen under the sun and it is prevalent among men—

a man to whom God has given riches and wealth and honor so that his soul lacks nothing of all that he desires; yet God has not empowered him to eat from them, for a foreigner enjoys them. This is vanity and a severe affliction.

If a man fathers a hundred children*i and lives many years, however many they be, but his soul is not satisfied with good things and he does not even have a proper*i burial, then*i I say, “Better the miscarriage than he,
for it comes in futility and goes into obscurity; and its name is covered in obscurity.
It never sees the sun and it never knows anything;*i it is better off than he.
Even if the other*i man lives a thousand years twice and does not enjoy good things—do not all go to one place?”
All*p a man’s labor is for his mouth and yet the appetite is not satisfied.
For what advantage does the wise man have over the fool? What advantage*i does the poor man have, knowing how*i to walk before the living?
What the eyes see is better than what the soul desires. This too is futility and a striving after wind.
Whatever*p exists has already been named, and it is known what man is; for he cannot dispute with him who is stronger than he is.
For there are many words which increase futility. What then*i is the advantage to a man?
For who knows what is good for a man during his*i lifetime, during*i the few years of his futile life? He will spend them like a shadow. For who can tell a man what will be after him under the sun?
